Fig 17 Research Paper Theoretical study on the C-C coupling mechanism of CO2 electroreduction on bimetallic sites embedded in N-doped carbon catalysts Hui Gao Writing – original draft Visualization Software Methodology Investigation Data curation Peng Jin Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (eCO2RR) can produce fuels, valuable chemicals, and help achieve carbon neutrality. However, obtaining target C2 products (e.g., ethylene and ethanol) with high activity and selectivity is still challenging. In this work, we chose the CoCu/CoNi dual atoms incorporated N-doped graphene (CoCuN6-gra) and C2N (CoNi-C2N) as the model catalysts to study the detailed eCO2RR process by using density functional theory calculations. The results reveal that CoCuN6-gra and CoNi-C2N both exhibit good catalytic activity and selectivity for ethylene with low limiting potentials (-0.56 and -0.50 V) and energy barriers (0.56 and 0.62 eV). The C-C coupling reaction prefers to occur at the *CO+*CHO → *COCHO step on CoCuN6-gra and *CHOH+*CO → *CHOHCO step on CoNi-C2N rather than their previous *CO+*CO → *COCO. Quantum chemistry wavefunction analyses rationalize this reaction difference and further disclose that three important characteristics could help achieve the C-C coupling: (1) weakened interactions between metal site and intermediate; (2) lowered orbital components of adsorbate carbon atoms in the metal-carbon bonds; (3) reduced electrostatic repulsion between the two coupling carbon atoms after accepting electrons from the hydrogen and/or metal atoms. Our work not only demonstrates the promising eCO2RR performance of the emerging CoCuN6-gra and CoNi-C2N dual-atom catalysts, but also provides a novel and in-depth wavefunction understanding for the rational design of more electrocatalysts to obtain various multicarbon products. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dual-atom catalyst CO2 reduction DFT Wavefunction analysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The massive consumption of fossil fuels produced huge amounts of carbon dioxide (CO2), which caused a series of serious problems such as greenhouse effect and environmental pollution. Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (eCO2RR) driven by the electricity generated from various renewable energies (e.g., solar, tide and wind energy) can not only mitigate the CO2 emission, but also produce high-value chemicals and fuels in an eco-friendly way [1–5]. Among the different eCO2RR products, C2 compounds such as ethylene (C2H4) and ethanol (C2H5OH) are rather attractive due to their high volumetric energy densities and important applications for synthesizing long-chain hydrocarbon fuels [6–10]. However, their formations involve multiple electron transfer reaction steps and require the C-C coupling process, and also have to compete with the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [11]. Currently, copper-based electrocatalysts can generate a series of C1 -C3 products, but they usually suffer from high limiting potential and low selectivity [12–14]. Therefore, efficient catalysts for selectively catalyzing eCO2RR toward C2 products with remarkable activity are highly desirable. Originated from the innovative concept of single-atom catalysis [15–19], emerging dual-atom catalysts (DACs) feature high atomic utilization, more flexible catalytic sites and complex synergistic effects. They exhibit excellent catalytic performances for many important electrochemical reactions such as HER, CO2RR, oxygen reduction/evolution reaction (ORR/OER) and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [20–28]. In particular, the two neighboring metal atoms in DACs can provide necessary active sites to enable the key C-C coupling in eCO2RR, thus exhibiting high activity and selectivity toward C2+ deep reduction products [29,30]. Recently, the DACs based on various N-doped carbon substrates show high selectivity for C2 products. Experimentally, Sun et al. reported that Cu2/N-doped carbon catalyst can selectively convert CO2 to C2H4 with a Faradaic efficiency of 34.9 % at the current density of 33.6 mA cm−2 [31]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the CuCu dual site not only promotes the *CO adsorption, but also lowers the coupling energy barrier between two *CO. Theoretically, Chen et al. computationally screened 21 homo and hetero dual-metal incorporated N-doped graphene catalysts, and predicted six M1M2N6-gra (M1M2 = CrCu, MnCu, CoCo, CoNi, CoCu, NiCu) DACs as promising candidates for obtaining C2 products [32]. In addition, C2N-based DACs also exhibit great potential toward C2 products [33,34]. For example, Xie et al. reported that the synergistic effects of dual atoms on CuFe@C2N significantly enhance the adsorption for the *CO intermediates, and the catalyst has high selectivity toward C2H5OH with the maximum ΔG value of 0.55 eV [35]. Li et al. constructed single-atom catalysts (M/C2N, M = Co, Ni) and bimetallic catalysts (M2/C2N), and found that NiCo/C2N can better adsorb and activate CO2 than M/C2N, thus promoting the deep reduction of CO2 to C2H4 [36]. Huang et al.’s DFT calculations also revealed that heteronuclear CoNi-C2N can generate C2H4 at −0.75 V [37]. Besides the carbon-based DACs, Shao et al. recently synthesized homonuclear Cu2 DACs based on ultrathin boron imidazolate layers, which show much enhanced selectivity toward the C2H4 product than the single-metal counterparts due to the effective cooperation between the two metal sites [38]. All these experimental and theoretical progresses demonstrate the great potential of DACs for converting CO2 to C2 products. However, there are many fundamental problems yet to be addressed for the eCO2RR catalyzed by DACs. For example, most of current theoretical studies only focus on calculating the free energy profiles, but very few efforts are devoted to disclosing the key C-C coupling mechanism [39]. The differences between different C-C coupling steps and what factors determine when the coupling will occur are still unclear. In addition, how will the adsorbate-adsorbate and adsorbate-catalyst interactions affect the coupling process? These are also very important for understanding the C-C bond formation and choosing suitable catalyst substrate to achieve deep CO2 reduction. In this work, DFT calculations were carried out to investigate the whole eCO2RR on the typical N-doped graphene (CoCuN6-gra) and C2N-based (CoNi-C2N) DACs. They are good model catalysts differing in metal type, coordination environment and support materials, and both have shown great potentials in producing C2 products. After demonstrating their good activity and selectivity toward C2 products, we delved into the detailed C-C bond formation mechanism. In particular, powerful wavefunction analysis methods were used to deeply understand the differences between different coupling steps. By this means, critical geometric and electronic structure characteristics as well as various adsorbate-adsorbate (catalyst) interactions were underscored to facilitate the C-C coupling reaction both thermodynamically and kinetically. The remainder of the paper is structured as follows. Section 2 describes the detailed computational methods. Section 3 separately presents the structures, electronic properties, reaction mechanisms and wavefunction analyses for the two DACs. Finally, a brief summary is provided in Section 4. 2 Computational methods Periodic calculations were performed in the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [40]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional[41] and the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [42] and corresponding pseudopotentials were used. The weak interactions in the structures were described by the Grimme's DFT-D3 [43] dispersion correction method. A cutoff energy of 500 eV was set for the plane wave basis set. The convergence thresholds are 10−5 eV for the energy and 0.02 eV/Å for the force. A vacuum space of 16 Å was applied along the z-direction to avoid the interactions between two periodic units. Considering the large cell size of 14.67 Å × 12.85 Å × 16.00 Å for CoCuN6-gra and 14.34 Å × 12.42 Å × 16.00 Å for CoNi-C2N, the first Brillouin zone was sampled by using the 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh. According to the test, the above parameters can provide sufficient accuracy for our system (Fig. S1). The VASPsol [44,45] implicit solvation model was used to simulate the effect of water solvent, and the transition state (TS) was calculated by using the nudged elastic band (NEB) method [46]. The structural stability of the catalyst is evaluated by calculating the formation energy (E f) of metal atoms incorporated into the N-doped carbon system: (1) E f = E CoCuN 6 − gra − E N 6 − gra − E Co − E Cu or (2) E f = E CoNi − C 2 N − E C 2 N − E Co − E Ni where E CoCuN6-gra, E CoNi-C2N, E N6-gra, E C2N, E Co, E Cu and E Ni represent the total energies of the CoCuN6-gra and CoNi-C2N, N-doped graphene and C2N without metals, and the Co, Cu and Ni atoms in the most stable bulk structures, respectively. The adsorption energy (E ads) of an intermediate on the catalyst surface was calculated as (3) E ads = E total − E catal − E int where E total, E catal and E int are the total energies of the catalyst with adsorbed intermediate, isolated catalyst and isolated intermediate, respectively. The Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) along the reaction was calculated as (4) Δ G = Δ E + Δ ZPE − T Δ S where ΔE is the electronic energy difference, ΔZPE and ΔS are the changes in zero-point energy and in entropy, respectively. T is the temperature (298.15 K). The computational hydrogen electrode model [47] was used to calculate the free energy of a proton-electron pair as a half of the free energy of isolated H2. The limiting potential (U L) represents the minimum potential needed to make each step of an electrochemical reaction occur, and was calculated as (5) U L = − Δ G max / e where ΔG max is the maximum free energy change of the eCO2RR. For the wavefunction analyses, single-point calculations were performed based on the cluster models of above optimized structures using the Gaussian 16 package [48] to obtain the wavefunction files. The standard 6–31G* all-electron basis sets [49] were used for the H, C, N and O atoms, whereas the Stuttgart/Dresden quasi-relativistic effective core potential (ECP) and the corresponding basis sets (SDD) [50] were chosen for Co, Cu and Ni. Together with the PBE-D3 functional, the current theoretical level is denoted as PBE-D3/6–31G*∼SDD. Mayer bond order (MBO), natural population analysis (NPA) charge, quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) [51], independent gradient model based on Hirshfeld partition (IGMH) [52] and localized molecular orbital (LMO) analyses [53] were performed using the Multiwfn package [54]. All structures were visualized by using the VESTA [55] and VMD [56] programs. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 CoCuN6-gra catalyst 3.1.1 Structure and electronic property The optimized periodic structure of CoCuN6-gra is planar with the two metal atoms perfectly embedded into the graphene framework (Fig. 1 a). The bond lengths between the metal atoms and their three nitrogen neighbours vary from 1.86 to 1.97 Å. The Co-Cu distance is 2.41 Å. These values are all shorter than the sum of covalent radii of the corresponding component atoms (Table S1). Thus, covalent Co-Cu and Co/Cu-N bonds are formed to enhance the system stability. This is also confirmed by the electron localization function (ELF), which shows high electron accumulation at the bonding regions (Fig. 1b). As a result, the formation energy of CoCuN6-gra catalyst is rather negative (−7.85 eV), indicating its good thermodynamic stability. After investigating the structural characteristics, we continued to study the electronic properties of CoCuN6-gra. Charge density difference indicates that there is significant electron transfer between the metals and six surrounding N atoms, suggesting that both metals donate some electrons to the nitrogen-doped graphene substrate (Fig. 1c). Consistently, Bader charge analyses reveal that the Co and Cu atoms hold the positive charges of +0.64 |e| and +0.66 |e|, respectively (Fig. 1d). Such electron transfer interactions between metal and nonmetal atoms can help stabilize the bimetallic sites. In addition, density of state (DOS, Fig. 1e) shows significant orbital hybridizations between the M-3d (M = metal) and N-2p states, further confirming the strong M-N coordination interactions. The d-band center (ε d) of Co site is much higher than that of Cu (−0.60 vs. −2.79 eV), and Co thus may have stronger adsorption ability than Cu according to the d-band center theory [57], resulting in their different catalytic activities. Fig. 1f describes the electronic band structure of the CoCuN6-gra catalyst. The direct band gap (E g) is as small as 0.09 eV (which may be underestimated at the PBE level but will not affect the main conclusions), suggesting that CoCuN6-gra can accelerate the electron transfer between catalyst and reaction intermediates and serve as a good electrocatalyst. 3.1.2 Adsorption of CO2 The adsorption and activation of CO2 molecule on the catalyst surface is the first step of eCO2RR. To find the most stable CO2 adsorption structure on CoCuN6-gra, the Co site, Cu site and Co-Cu bridge site were all considered with various initial adsorption configurations on them. The optimal adsorption configuration is shown in Fig. 2 b, and other higher-energy adsorption structures are summarized in Fig. S2. The CO2 molecule tends to be adsorbed at the Co-Cu bridge site, and its C atom and one O atom reside on the top of Co and Cu atoms, respectively. The more favorable simultaneous adsorption on the two metal sites than other possible (top, bridge, hollow) mono-metal/nonmetal sites should be ascribed to the strong metal-adsorbate interactions and effective synergy of the two metals (similar conclusions also found in CoNi-C2N; vide infra). Different from the linear configuration (O-C-O: 180°) in isolated state (Fig. 2a), the adsorbed CO2 becomes obviously curved (O-C-O: 136°), and the C-O bond length also increases from 1.17 Å to 1.23/1.25 Å. The Co-C and Cu-O distances are 1.97 and 2.37 Å, respectively, both of which are shorter than in other adsorption configurations (Fig. S2). The CO2 adsorption energy on CoCuN6-gra is −0.12 eV, indicating that the adsorption is exothermic and could occur spontaneously. Fig. 2c depicts the calculated charge density difference upon the CO2 adsorption. The charge accumulation is mainly concentrated on the Co-C and Cu-O bonds, suggesting the presence of Co-Cu synergistic effect to enhance the CO2 adsorption. Bader charge analyses revealed that CO2 receives 0.66 e from the catalyst (Fig. 2c). The accepted electrons occupy its anti-bonding π* orbital (LUMO in Fig. 2a), thus causing the elongated C-O bonds and increased negative charges of component atoms (Fig. 2c). Evidently, CoCuN6-gra can effectively adsorb and activate the CO2 molecule, making the subsequent hydrogenation and C-C coupling feasible. 3.1.3 Reaction mechanism of C2 products formation Fig. 3 shows all the possible eCO2RR paths on CoCuN6-gra considered in this work. By investigating various configurations and orientations of reaction intermediates at each active site, the lowest-energy ones are found and their adsorption structures are shown in Fig. S3. For the convenience of discussion, all the calculated zero-point energies and entropy corrections for related free or adsorbed species are given in Table S2, and Table S3 summarizes all the calculated free energy changes along the above reaction paths. According to different addition positions (O or C), the first hydrogenation of adsorbed *CO2 (* represents the catalyst) may produce either *COOH or *OCHO. The calculated free energy profiles indicate that the formation of *COOH is less endothermic than *OCHO (0.30 vs 0.40 eV, Table S3). Thus, the catalyst favors the formation of *COOH, whose further hydrogenation results in *CO (with a H2O molecule released). The *CO is adsorbed at the Co-Cu bridge site with the C atom bonding with the metals (Fig. S3). In addition, it is also difficult to desorb from the catalyst surface (ΔG: 0.93 eV), thus making the further reduction possible. After the formation of *CO, three paths are possible: hydrogenation to form *CHO, hydrogenation to form *COH, or adsorption of the second CO to form co-adsorbed *CO+*CO (+ without space at both sides means coadsorption in this work). The former two paths may lead to the C1 products. Among the three paths, the ΔG value for forming the *CO+*CO intermediate (0.08 eV) is much lower than those of generating *CHO (0.48 eV) and *COH (1.83 eV), thus favoring the C-C coupling and C2 products. In *CO+*CO, different from the Co-Cu bridge site for the first CO adsorption, the second CO tends to be adsorbed at the Co site due to the lower adsorption energy than on the Cu site (−1.13 vs −0.76 eV, Fig. S4). The subsequent C-C coupling reaction in eCO2RR may take place via two different pathways. One is the direct coupling between two co-adsorbed *CO (i.e., *CO+*CO), the other is the coupling between *CO and its hydrogenated intermediate (such as *CHO and *COH) [58-61]. The results show that after the formation of *CO+*CO, it will be further protonated to form *CO+*CHO with a free energy change of 0.56 eV, which is much lower than other two possible intermediates, *CO+*COH (1.48 eV) and the coupling *COCO (0.80 eV). Subsequently, the C-C coupling of *CO+*CHO can produce *COCHO, or it may undergo further hydrogenation to form *CHO+*CHO or *CO+*CHOH. The corresponding free energy changes are −0.07, 0.30, and 0.31 eV, respectively, indicating that the formation of *COCHO is thermodynamically more favorable. The subsequent protonation of *COCHO may result in four intermediates, namely *CHOCHO, *COCHOH, *COCH2O and *COHCHO with ΔG values of −0.13, 0.00, 0.18 and 0.59 eV, respectively. The energy change trend of the *COCHO → *COCH2O/*COHCHO step is qualitatively consistent with the literature [32]. However, the above results reveal that the formation of *CHOCHO/*COCHOH is energetically more preferable than the reported *COCH2O/*COHCHO. The two new *COCHO → *CHOCHO and *COCHO → *COCHOH processes have similar ΔG changes, indicating that both of them are possible. As the next step, both *CHOCHO and *COCHOH will form the same *CH2CHO species after several continuous hydrogenation processes. The corresponding pathways are *CHOCHO → *CHOHCHO → *CHCHO (released H2O) → *CH2CHO with the ΔG values of −0.09, 0.02, −0.84 eV, and *COCHOH → *CHCO (released H2O) → *CH2CO → *CH2CHO with the ΔG values of −0.47, −0.58 and 0.01 eV. For *CH2CHO, its further protonation forms *CH2CHOH with a ΔG of −0.24 eV, indicating that this step is easy to occur. Further reduction of *CH2CHOH may result in *CHCH2 and simultaneously release a H2O molecule (ΔG: 0.18 eV). The protonation of *CHCH2 then produces the final *C2H4 product (ΔG: −0.75 eV). Alternatively, the reduction of *CH2CHOH may also form *CH2CH2OH (ΔG: 0.23 eV) and further yield the final C2H5OH product, which can be released spontaneously from the catalyst surface. In comparison, the formation of *CHCH2 is more favorable than *CH2CH2OH, indicating that C2H4 may be the main product of eCO2RR on CoCuN6-gra. Fig. 4 a shows the whole free energy diagram for the two C2 products. The complete reaction pathway toward C2H4 is as follows: CO2 → *COOH → *CO → *CO+*CO → *CO+*CHO → *COCHO → *CHOCHO → *CHOHCHO → *CHCHO → *CH2CHO → *CH2CHOH → *CHCH2 → *C2H4. Along the reaction, *CO+*CO → *CO+*CHO is the potential determining step with the maximum ΔG value of 0.56 eV. Accordingly, the limiting potential is as low as −0.56 V on CoCuN6-gra (Fig. S5), which is less than those of recently reported FeCo@C2N (−0.63 V) [34], FeFe-grafiN6 (−0.68 V) [60], and CuFe@C3N4 (−0.64 V) [35] DACs. Thus, CoCuN6-gra could serve as a good catalyst to obtain C2 products such as C2H4 with high activity and selectivity. As shown above, there are two possible C-C coupling steps along the reaction path to obtain the final C2 products, coadsorbed *CO+*CO → *COCO or its hydrogenated *CO+*CHO → *COCHO, which are then detailly compared in terms of kinetics. The C-C coupling energy barrier of the former is 0.91 eV (Fig. 4b), which is higher than the fast kinetic threshold at room temperature (0.75 eV) [62], indicating that the coupling reaction is difficult to occur kinetically. For *CO+*CHO → *COCHO, however, the coupling barrier of 0.56 eV (Fig. 4c) is much lower. Consistently, it has been found that the kinetic barriers decrease with the increased hydrogenation degree of the reaction intermediates [63,64]. In addition, the latter step also has negative reaction free energy compared to the rather positive one for the former (−0.07 vs. 0.80 eV, Table S3). Therefore, the C-C coupling reaction on the CoCuN6-gra should occur at the *CO+*CHO intermediate rather than at *CO+*CO in terms of both thermodynamics and kinetics [32,65]. Furthermore, eCO2RR occurred in aqueous solution may compete with the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Therefore, the catalytic activity of HER is further evaluated. The adsorption energy of *CO2 is significantly lower than that of *H (−0.12 vs. −0.06 eV, Fig. S6), demonstrating that the catalyst preferentially adsorbs CO2 and has a good inhibition effect on HER. 3.1.4 Wavefunction analyses of the C-C coupling processes To further understand when and why the key C-C coupling will occur and the thermodynamic/kinetic difference between the *CO+*CO → *COCO and *CO+*CHO → *COCHO steps, an in-depth study was conducted by using several wavefunction analysis methods (MBO, LMO, QTAIM, NPA and IGMH) in quantum chemistry. To this end, the corresponding cluster models were constructed from the above periodic ones by maintaining the catalytically reactive centers and breaking the peripheral C-C bonds with dangling bonds saturated by hydrogen atoms (Fig. 5 ). A recent study shows that the structural characteristics and electronic properties of graphene-based catalysts from periodic calculations can be well reproduced in the cluster models [66]. Our benchmark calculations also indicate that the cluster model can give very similar energy profile for the C-C coupling reactions as the periodic one. In addition, the calculations using more accurate hybrid functionals (B3LYP and M06–2X) also present consistent results as the current PBE-D3 method. The C-C coupling processes involve both the formation of new bonds and cleavage of existing bonds. To understand the reactions in detail, it is thus important to track the bond length and bond order changes of key chemical bonds. First, for the chemical bonds formed between the adsorbates and catalyst (i.e., M-C bonds), the Cu-C1 bond in *CO+*CO and the Cu-C1 and Co-C1 bonds in *CO+*CHO all break after the C1-C2 coupling (Fig. 5). These changes can be seen from their markedly increased bond lengths (Cu-C1: 2.06 to 2.53 Å; Cu-C1 and Co-C1: 2.21 to 2.75 Å and 1.93 to 2.77 Å, respectively, Fig. 6 a, b). Accordingly, their MBOs all obviously decrease (Fig. 6c and d). At the same time, the C1-C2 distance greatly decreases from 2.42 (2.34) to 1.48 (1.53) Å, and corresponding bond order increases from 0.05 (0.07) to 0.81 (0.82), confirming the formation of C-C single bond. These bond changes can be rationalized by considering that the initial bonds all have much smaller MBO values than the newly formed C1-C2 bonds (Cu-C1: 0.52 vs. C1-C2: 0.81, Cu-C1/Co-C1: 0.35/0.75 vs. C1-C2: 0.82, Fig. 6c, d). The changes also comply with the trend that the systems energetically tend to reduce the weaker interactions between the metal atoms and C1/C2 to form the stronger covalent C1-C2 bond. By comparison, although the bond lengths of Co-C1 and Co-C2 in *CO+*CO → *COCO and Co-C2 in *CO+*CHO → *COCHO increase (1.76 to 1.81 Å and 1.72 to 1.80 Å; 1.74 to 1.84 Å) and corresponding bond orders decrease (0.97 to 0.95 and 1.36 to 1.02; 1.28 to 0.96), they are not broken. The reason may be that these initial M-C bonds are all stronger than the final C1-C2 bonds (MBO: 0.97/1.36/1.28 vs. 0.81/0.82). Furthermore, during the *CO+*CO → *CO+*CHO conversion process, the MBO values of Co-C1/Co-C2/Cu-C1 decrease from 0.97/1.36/0.52 to 0.75/1.28/0.35, indicating that further hydrogenation of *CO+*CO can reduce the interactions between the adsorbate and catalyst surface, thereby facilitating the formation of C-C bonds. Similarly, recent DFT studies also revealed that the existence of bridged Cl− between the Cu dimer in boron imidazolate layers can enhance the catalytic selectivity toward C2H4 by weakening the interactions between CO2 and reaction centers [38]. Next, the chemical bonds for the adsorbed intermediates are studied. Their formations of new C-C bonds were both accompanied by the elongation and decreased bond order of most C-O bonds (Fig. 6a, b). However, when *CO+*CO converts to *CO+*CHO, the C1-C2 interaction between the two *CO obviously increases (d: 2.42 to 2.34 Å; MBO: 0.05 to 0.07) and C1-O1 bond of first *CO weakens (d: 1.18 to 1.24 Å; MBO: 1.82 to 1.61). These structure and bond order changes indicate that the hydrogenation of *CO+*CO enhances the interaction between C1 and C2 and makes them closer and ready to couple. The elongated C1-O1 bond could be due to the filling of electron into the antibonding molecular orbital [64]. Moreover, the C1-C2 bond order in *COCHO is slightly higher than that in *COCO (0.82 vs. 0.81), indicative of the stronger covalent C1-C2 bond in the former. To investigate the changes of bonding nature during the C-C coupling processes, electron density topology analyses were further conducted by using the QTAIM method. Fig. 7 a depicts the obtained molecular graphs of the *CO+*CO, *COCO, *CO+*CHO and *COCHO intermediates, and Table S4 presents the corresponding topology parameters. After the C-C coupling, one bond critical point (BCP) appears between C1 and C2 in both *COCO and *COCHO, confirming the formation of C-C bond. First, for the bonds formed between the adsorbates and catalyst, one BCP is found for Co-C1, Co-C2 and Cu-C1 in the initial states. The Cu-C1 BCP disappears in *COCO, whereas both the Cu-C1 and Co-C1 BCPs are absent in *COCHO (Fig. 7a). In addition, the electron densities (ρ bcp) of unbroken Co-C1 and Co-C2 in *CO+*CO → *COCO and Co-C2 in *CO+*CHO → *COCHO all decrease (0.16 to 0.15 a.u. and 0.17 to 0.15 a.u.; 0.16 to 0.14 a.u., Table S4). The corresponding total energy densities (H bcp) also become less negative (−0.07 to −0.06 a.u. and −0.08 to −0.06 a.u.; −0.08 to −0.06 a.u.). All these changes reveal that the interactions between metal sites and intermediates are weakened in the C-C coupling process. Furthermore, during the *CO+*CO → *CO+*CHO protonation process, the ρ bcp values of Co-C1/Co-C2/Cu-C1 decrease from 0.16/0.17/0.08 a.u. to 0.12/0.16/0.06 a.u., indicating that further hydrogenation of *CO+*CO can reduce the covalent interactions between the adsorbate and catalyst surface, thereby promoting the formation of C-C bonds. Next, the BCPs for the adsorbed intermediates are studied. In both coupling processes, the ρ bcp values decrease and H bcp values become less negative for the BCPs of most C-O bonds, indicating the weakening of their covalent interactions during the formation of C-C bonds. This is consistent with the results of the bond order analyses. Additionally, the larger ρ bcp value (0.25 vs. 0.24 a.u.) for the C1-C2 bond in *COCHO than in *COCO confirm that the formed C-C bond in the former is stronger than in the latter. To make a short summary, all the above bond length, bond order and electron density parameter changes reveal that the weaker interactions between metal sites and adsorbates will cause the latter tend to undergo coupling to form stronger C-C bond. In addition, the coupling is easy to occur when the adsorbate has shorter initial C-C distance and longer C-O bond. All these factors should account for the negative reaction energy and reduced reaction barrier of the C-C coupling reaction at the *CO+*CHO intermediate. To understand the orbital interactions between the metals and the C atoms of the intermediates, the LMOs and orbital composition analysis were then employed (Fig. 8 ). One σ bond forms between the C1 and C2 atoms in the final states of both *COCO and *COCHO, confirming the occurrence of C-C coupling. The bond is formed by hybridizing both the C-2s and 2p atomic orbitals. In *CO+*CO → *COCO, the Co atom always forms two σ bonds with C1 and C2, but its contributions to the orbitals increase after the C-C coupling (26 % to 49 %; 27 % to 69 %). The changes mainly involve the Co-3d orbitals, which increase from 67 % to 72 % and from 39 % to 88 %. At the same time, the orbital components of both C1 and C2 atoms decrease (C1: 74 % to 51 %; C2: 73 % to 31 %). For C2, its 2p orbital replaces 2s and becomes dominated in the orbital component. For *CO+*CHO → *COCHO, two σ bonds are also found between Co and C1/C2 in the initial state. But after the C1-C2 bond formation, Co-C1 bond breaks. Co and C2 show increased (25 % to 62 %) and decreased (75 % to 38 %) contributions to the Co-C2 bond, respectively. The Co-3d (25 % to 85 %) and C2–2p (25 % to 60 %) orbitals also increase their contributions. All these results indicate that the two C atoms should reduce their participance in the M-C orbital interactions to have more hybrid 2s2p orbitals to achieve their coupling. In addition, for the *CO+*CO → *CO+*CHO hydrogenation process, the orbital composition of C1 in Co-C1 bond markedly decreases (74 % to 43 %) with that of C2 in Co-C2 almost unchanged, which may be beneficial to the C-C coupling. The NPA charges were also calculated to reveal the different electrostatic attractions between C1 and C2 in the two C-C coupling processes (Fig. 7b). For *CO+*CO → *COCO, C1 and C2 in initial *CO+*CO both have rather positive charges (+0.32 |e| and +0.41 |e|), indicating strong electrostatic repulsion between them. When *CO+*CO converts to *CO+*CHO, the positive charge of C1 is greatly reduced to +0.02 |e| and that of C2 is almost unchanged (+0.42 |e|), which significantly weakens the electrostatic repulsion between C1 and C2 and makes the coupling more favorable. The C1 charge difference between the two initial states is probably because the Co and H atoms both lose electrons in *CO+*CHO, whereas Cu and O1 only accept small amount of these electrons, resulting in surplus electrons transferred to the central C1 atom. Thus, further hydrogen at the C1 site facilitates the C-C coupling by reducing the positive charge at the carbon atom. Finally, IGMH analyses were carried out to understand the strength of weak interactions between the co-adsorbed intermediates in *CO+*CO and *CO+*CHO. The two initial intermediates involved in the C-C coupling reaction can be considered as two fragments, namely fragment 1 (C1O1 or C1HO1) and fragment 2 (C2O2). The IGMH method defines a δginter function to study interfragment interactions [52]. As shown in Fig. 7c, blue and green regions indicate stronger and weaker interactions, and red regions indicate repulsive interaction. The attractive interactions exist between the two fragments in both initial states, as indicated by the large blue and green IGMH regions. In addition, the smaller red regions also indicate the presence of partial repulsion between the two fragments. To distinguish the two initial states, quantitative analyses using atom δg index (δG atom) and atomic pair δg index (δG pair) were conducted to study the contributions of specific atoms and atom pairs to the total δginter between the two fragments. The atomic contributions of C1 in fragment 1 and C2 in fragment 2 to the interfragment interaction in *CO+*CHO are both larger than those in *CO+*CO (δG atom: 0.23 vs. 0.21 and 0.28 vs. 0.22, Fig. 7c). Similarly, the C1-C2 atom pair in *CO+*CHO also has slightly more contribution than that in *CO+*CO (δG pair: 0.19 vs. 0.18). These results indicate that the attraction between C1 and C2 is stronger in *CO+*CHO than *CO+*CO, which is also consistent with the calculated larger bond order of the former than the latter (MBO: 0.07 vs. 0.05). Their increased attraction thus promotes the formation of C1-C2 bond. To give a summary of this section, the above results show that CoCuN6-gra can selectively reduce CO2 to ethylene with the C-C coupling occurring at the *CO+*CHO → *COCHO step. The coupling is facilitated by weakening the metal-adsorbate interactions, lowering the orbital components of adsorbate carbon atoms in the metal-carbon bonds, and reducing the electrostatic repulsion between the two coupling carbon atoms. To extend to more N-doped carbon DACs, the eCO2RR on CoNi-C2N was further investigated in the next section. 3.2 CoNi-C2N catalyst 3.2.1 Structure and electronic property The optimized periodic planar C2N structure has the lattice parameter of 8.28 Å (Fig. 9 a), which is well consistent with the experimental value of 8.30 Å [67], confirming the reliability of current level of theory. Due to the large pores in C2N, when two metal atoms (M = Co, Ni) are doped to form CoNi-C2N, two different structures named as I and II can be obtained with different M-N coordination environments. The optimized structures of CoNi-C2N(I) and CoNi-C2N(II) are shown in Fig. 9b and c, and both are planar with the two metal atoms perfectly embedded into the C2N substrate. The M-N distances range from 1.82 to 1.89 Å and Co-Ni distance is 2.13/2.07 Å, all of which are close to or shorter than the covalent radii sum of corresponding component atoms (Table S5). Thus, covalent Co/Ni-N and Co-Ni bonds are formed to enhance the system stability. Because structure I has a lower formation energy than structure II (−5.19 vs. −5.01 eV), it represents the CoNi-C2N catalyst in this work. The electron localization function (ELF) reveals high electron accumulation at its Co/Ni-N and Co-Ni bonding regions (Fig. 10 a), further confirming the formation of strong Co/Ni-N and Co-Ni bonds. We continued to study the electronic properties of CoNi-C2N. Charge density difference indicates that two metals both transfer electrons to the surrounding nitrogen atoms (Fig. 10b), which is also confirmed by the calculated positive charges of +0.64 |e| and +0.53 |e| for the Co and Ni atoms, respectively (Fig. 10c). Such electron transfer interactions between metal and nonmetal atoms can help stabilize the bimetallic sites. In addition, the M-3d and N-2p states exhibit significant orbital hybridizations in the density of state (DOS, Fig. 10d) and further confirm the strong M-N coordination interactions. The Co site has a higher d-band center (ε d) than Ni (−0.96 vs. −1.37 eV), suggesting that it has stronger adsorption ability than the latter [57]. Additionally, CoNi-C2N has a small direct band gap of 0.02 eV (Fig. 10e), indicative of its good electron transfer capability. 3.2.2 Adsorption of CO2 Different initial CO2 adsorption configurations were considered on its Co site, Ni site, and Co-Ni bridge site, resulting in three different adsorption structures. Among them, the most stable adsorption configuration (E ads: −0.59 eV) is found when the CO2 molecule adsorbs on the Co-Ni bridge site with its C atom and one O atom residing on top of the Co and Ni atoms, respectively (Fig. 11 a). The adsorbed CO2 molecule becomes obviously curved (O-C-O: 129.8°), and the bond angle is smaller than in other high-energy adsorption configurations (Fig. S7). The C-O bond length increases from 1.17 Å to 1.22/1.30 Å. The Co-C and Ni-O distances are 1.91 Å and 1.88 Å, respectively. Compared to CoCuN6-gra, the adsorbed CO2 on CoNi-C2N has a smaller angle (129.8° vs. 136.0°), longer C-O bond (1.22/1.30 vs. 1.23/1.25 Å), and shorter distance (1.91/1.88 vs. 1.97/2.37 Å) to the active sites, all of which indicate that the latter has a stronger adsorption and activation capability for CO2. This is also confirmed by the more negative adsorption energy of CO2 on CoNi-C2N than CoCuN6-gra (−0.59 vs. −0.12 eV). The calculated charge density difference upon the CO2 adsorption shows that the charge accumulation is mainly concentrated on the Co-C and Ni-O bonds (Fig. 11b), indicating that the presence of Co-Ni synergy to enhance the CO2 adsorption. The adsorbed CO2 receives electrons (0.69 e) from the catalyst, which occupy the anti-bonding π* orbital of CO2, thus leading to the elongated C-O bonds. Therefore, CoNi-C2N can effectively activate the CO2 molecule, making the further reduction feasible. 3.2.3 Reaction mechanism of C2 products formation The complete eCO2RR reaction pathway on CoNi-C2N is shown in Fig. 12 . Fig. S8 summarizes the lowest energy structures of the reaction intermediates. Table S6 and Table S7 tabulate all the calculated zero-point energies/entropy corrections for relevant adsorbed intermediates and the free energy changes of all reaction steps, respectively. First, the adsorbed *CO2 undergoes a one-step hydrogenation process to form *COOH or *OCHO. The generation of *OCHO is slightly more exothermic than *COOH (−0.40 vs. −0.34 eV, Table S7), indicating that both pathways are possible. However, the further hydrogenation of *COOH to form *CO (accompanied by the release of a water molecule) is an exothermic process (ΔG: −1.06 eV), while the hydrogenation of *OCHO to form *OCHOH is endothermic (ΔG: 0.58 eV), indicating that *CO is more likely to be generated. *CO adsorbs on the Co-Ni bridge site of CoNi-C2N (Fig. S8), where the C atom simultaneously bonds with two metal atoms. Such a stable adsorption configuration makes it difficult for *CO to desorb from the catalyst surface (ΔG: 2.05 eV), thus favorable for further reduction. After *CO is formed, it can be hydrogenated at either the C or O sites to generate *CHO or *COH intermediates. Alternatively, the second CO molecule may be adsorbed to form the co-adsorbed *CO+*CO intermediate. The further reduction of the first two intermediates may lead to C1 products. Compared to the formation of *CHO (ΔG: 0.87 eV) and *COH (ΔG: 0.97 eV), the formation of co-adsorbed *CO+*CO (ΔG: −0.48 eV) is easier, suggesting the tendency toward the C-C coupling and C2 products. In *CO+*CO, one CO is located at the Co-Ni bridge site, whereas the other is at the top of the Co site (Fig. S8). Subsequently, the C-C coupling process of *CO+*CO was investigated. However, the optimized coupled *COCO structure shows a large C-C distance of 2.45 Å, suggesting that *CO+*CO cannot directly form the C-C bond on CoNi-C2N (Fig. S9). Thus, *CO+*CO will be further protonated to form *CHO+*CO with a free energy change of 0.50 eV, which is lower than the formation of *CO+*COH (0.63 eV). The *CO+*CO → *CHO+*CO step also has a lower energy change compared to the *CO+*CO → *CO+*COH step reported in the literature [37], making it more favorable. Unlike the *CO+*CHO on CoCuN6-gra, the H atom is located on the *CO at the top of Co site in CoNi-C2N, rather than on the *CO at the Co-Ni bridge site [68]. The further hydrogenation of *CHO+*CO to form *CHOH+*CO has a ΔG value of 0.37 eV, which is significantly lower than the other two possible intermediates, *CHO+*CHO (ΔG: 1.34 eV) and the coupling *COCHO (ΔG: 1.00 eV). Subsequently, the C-C coupling of *CHOH+*CO can form *CHOHCO (ΔG: 0.47 eV), which is easier than the further hydrogenation to form *CH+*CO (with a H2O molecule released, ΔG: 1.11 eV). Next, the protonation of *CHOHCO forms *CHCO (with a H2O molecule released, ΔG: −0.71 eV) is exothermic and easy to occur. The hydrogenation of *CHCO may result in three intermediates, namely *CH2CO, *CHCOH, and *CHCHO with ΔG values of −0.05, −0.06 and 0.38 eV, respectively. The *CHCO → *CH2CO and *CHCO → *CHCOH processes are easier and have similar free energy changes, indicating that both of them are possible. Additionally, they will result in the same *CH2CHOH intermediate after several continuous hydrogenation processes: *CH2CO → *CH2CHO → *CH2CHOH (ΔG: 0.02 and −0.36 eV); *CHCOH → *CHCHOH → *CH2CHOH (ΔG values: 0.06 and −0.38 eV). In addition, *CH2CHO → *CH2CH2O is difficult to occur compared to *CH2CHO → *CH2CHOH (ΔG: 0.39 vs. −0.36 eV). Further reduction on *CH2CHOH will form three intermediates, namely *CH3CHOH, *CHCH2 and *CH2CH2OH with the ΔG values of 0.55, −0.19 and 0.23 eV, respectively. Thus, it is much easier to form *CHCH2. Finally, the protonation of *CHCH2 exothermically produces the final *C2H4 product (ΔG: −0.54 eV). Additionally, the protonation of *CH2CH2OH may also yield the minor product *OHCH2CH3 (i.e., adsorbed ethanol, ΔG: −1.39 eV). To give a summary, Fig. 13 a shows the whole free energy diagram from CO2 to the two C2 products. The complete reaction pathway toward C2H4 is CO2 → *COOH → *CO → *CO+*CO → *CHO+*CO → *CHOH+*CO → *CHOHCO → *CHCO → *CH2CO → *CH2CHO → *CH2CHOH → *CHCH2 → *C2H4. Along the reaction, *CO+*CO → *CO+*CHO is also the potential determining step as in CoCuN6-gra, with the maximum ΔG value of 0.50 eV. Accordingly, the limiting potential is as low as −0.50 V on CoNi-C2N, which is even less than CoCuN6-gra (−0.56 V). Thus, CoNi-C2N is also a very promising catalyst to obtain C2 products. As shown above, the co-adsorbed *CO+*CO cannot directly form C-C bond via the C-C coupling. Two possible C-C coupling steps along the reaction are *CHO+*CO → *COCHO and *CHOH+*CO → *CHOHCO, which are then detailly compared in terms of reaction kinetics. The C-C coupling energy barrier of the former is 1.28 eV (Fig. 13b), which is much higher than the fast kinetic threshold at room temperature (0.75 eV). In contrast, the coupling barrier of *CHOH+*CO → *CHOHCO is much lower (0.62 eV, Fig. 13c), and it also has a lower reaction free energy (ΔG: 0.47 vs. 1.00 eV, Table S7). Therefore, the C-C coupling reaction on the CoNi-C2N should occur at the *CHOH+*CO intermediate. Similarly, it has been reported that the C-C coupling step on Ni2P catalyst also proceeds through *CHOH+*CO → *CHOHCO [64]. Furthermore, the competition between eCO2RR and HER was investigated. Previous studies have shown that the thermodynamic limiting potential difference between CO2RR and HER (U L(CO2) - U L(H2)) can reflect the selectivity of reaction products, and a more positive value means higher selectivity towards CO2RR [69]. The value of U L(CO2) - U L(H2) is 0.23 V on CoNi-C2N, suggesting that the CoNi-C2N catalyst has a certain inhibitory effect on HER. 3.2.4 Wavefunction analyses of the C-C coupling processes To further understand the C-C coupling difference between the above *CHO+*CO → *COCHO and *CHOH+*CO → *CHOHCO steps, wavefunction analyses were conducted. In order to compare with the initial states of the two coupling processes, the *CO+*CO intermediate was also considered. Their corresponding cluster models are shown in Fig. 14 . First, for the chemical bonds between the adsorbates and catalyst (i.e., M-C bonds), the bond lengths of Co-C1, Ni-C1 and Co-C2 in *CHO+*CO → *COCHO increase (1.78 to 1.95 Å, 1.98 to 2.15 Å and 1.86 to 2.69 Å, Fig. 15 b) and corresponding bond orders decrease (0.88 to 0.70, 0.60 to 0.47 and 0.87 to 0.16, Fig. 15e). Similarly, the bond lengths of Co-C1, Ni-C1 and Co-C2 in *CHOH+*CO → *CHOHCO increase (1.81 to 2.19 Å, 1.89 to 1.93 Å and 1.79 to 2.00 Å) and the corresponding MBO values decrease (0.83 to 0.30, 0.79 to 0.78 and 1.28 to 0.78). At the same time, the C1-C2 distance significantly decreases from 2.45 (2.44) to 1.54 (1.45) Å, and corresponding bond order increases from 0.07 (0.08) to 0.84 (0.94), confirming the formation of C-C single bond. Additionally, compared to *CO+*CO, the bond orders of Co-C1/Ni-C1/Co-C2 in *CHO+*CO all decrease (0.90/0.80/1.29 to 0.88/0.60/0.87, Fig. 15d, e). The bond length of Co-C2 in *CHOH+*CO also increases (1.73 to 1.79 Å) and corresponding MBO values decreases (1.29 to 1.28). These results indicate that one or two H atoms added to the *CO+*CO can reduce the interactions between the adsorbate and catalyst surface, thereby facilitating the C-C bond formation. Next, we turned to the chemical bonds within the adsorbed intermediates. In both coupling processes, during the C-C bond formations, most C-O bonds are elongated with decreased bond orders (Fig 15b, c, e, f). For the *CO+*CO → *CHO+*CO → *CHOH+*CO stepwise hydrogenation process, the interaction between C1 and C2 significantly increases (d: 2.50 down to 2.45 to 2.44 Å; MBO: 0.04 up to 0.07 to 0.08), whereas the C2-O2 bond gradually weakens (d: 1.17 up to 1.22 to 1.32 Å; MBO: 2.00 down to 1.63 to 1.18). Thus, C1 and C2 become closer and ready to couple if increasing the hydrogenation degree of *CO+*CO. Additionally, the C1-C2 bond in *CHOHCO is stronger than that in *COCHO due to the shorter distance (1.45 vs. 1.54 Å) and larger MBO value (0.94 vs. 0.84) than the latter. The QTAIM analyses were carried out to further study the bonding change during the C-C coupling. Fig. 16 and Table S8 provide the obtained molecular graphs of *CO+*CO, *CHO+*CO, *COCHO, *CHOH+*CO and *CHOHCO and the corresponding electron density topology parameters, respectively. The formation of C-C bond between C1 and C2 in both *COCHO and *CHOHCO is confirmed from the presence of one bond critical point (BCP). First, one BCP is found for each of the Co-C1, Ni-C1, and Co-C2 bonds in the initial states. The BCPs of Co-C2 and Co-C1 disappear in *COCHO and *CHOHCO, respectively (Fig. 16). In addition, the ρ bcp of unbroken Co-C1 and Ni-C1 in *CHO+*CO → *COCHO and Ni-C1 and Co-C2 in *CHOH+*CO → *CHOHCO all decreases (0.15 to 0.11 a.u. and 0.09 to 0.07 a.u.; 0.12 to 0.11 a.u. and 0.16 to 0.10 a.u., Table S8). The H bcp of Co-C1 in the former and Co-C2 in the latter also become less negative (−0.07 to −0.04 a.u.; −0.07 to −0.03 a.u.), whereas the H bcp of Ni-C1 remains constant in both processes. These changes indicate that the interactions between metal sites and intermediates are weakened in the C-C coupling process. Furthermore, compared to *CO+*CO, the ρ bcp values of Co-C2 in *CO+*CHO and CHOH+*CO decrease (0.17 to 0.13 and 0.16 a.u.), and corresponding H bcp also become less negative (−0.08 to −0.05 and −0.07 a.u.). These indicate that further hydrogenation of the C2 and O2 sites in *CO+*CO can reduce the covalent interaction between the adsorbates and catalyst surface, thereby promoting the formation of the C-C bond. Next, the BCPs for the adsorbed intermediates are further studied. Consistent with the bond order analyses, during the formation of the C-C bonds, most C-O bonds in both coupling processes exhibit decreased ρ bcp values and less negative H bcp values, indicating the weakened covalent interactions. Additionally, the larger ρ bcp value and more negative H bcp value of the C1-C2 bond in *CHOHCO than in *COCHO (0.28 vs. 0.24 a.u.; −0.26 vs. −0.18 a.u.) all suggest that the C1-C2 bond formed in the former is stronger. All above results indicate that the C-C bond will become easier to form when the metal-adsorbate interactions are weaker and the adsorbate has shorter initial C-C distance and longer C-O bonds. All these factors should account for the lower free energy change and reaction barrier for the C-C coupling reaction at the *CHOH+*CO intermediate. The NPA charges were also calculated to reveal the different electrostatic attractions between C1 and C2 in *CO+*CO and two C-C coupling processes (Fig. 17 ). For the successive hydrogenation process of *CO+*CO → *CHO+*CO → *CHOH+*CO, when hydrogen atoms are sequentially added to the C2 and O2 sites, the positive charge of C2 significantly decreases (+0.38 |e| vs. +0.16 |e| vs. +0.06 |e|) and that of C1 initially increases slightly and then remains unchanged (+0.12 |e| vs. +0.17 |e| vs. +0.17 |e|), which significantly weakens the electrostatic repulsion between C1 and C2, thus facilitating the coupling reaction. This is consistent with the CoCuN6-gra case in that the smaller electrostatic repulsion between two atoms leads to lower coupling barrier. The large C2 charge difference among the three initial states may because the H1 and O2 atoms lose electrons in *CHO+*CO, whereas Co only gains some of these electrons, which thus also transfer to the central C2 atom. In addition, the H2 and Co atoms in *CHOH+*CO largely lose electrons, whereas O2 only accepts small number of electrons, resulting in the substantial electron transfer to the C2 atom. Therefore, further hydrogen at the C2 and O2 sites facilitates the C-C coupling by reducing the positive charges at the carbon atoms. By summarizing the charge results of the two catalysts, one can find that the charge distribution between the intermediates involved in C-C coupling reactions leads to different electrostatic repulsions, which then greatly affects the coupling. Further hydrogenation results in weaker electrostatic repulsion, thereby enhancing the efficiency of C-C coupling. Finally, a side-by-side comparison between the CoCuN6-gra and CoNi-C2N catalysts during eCO2RR can be made. Their obvious difference is that the C-C coupling occurs at *CHOH+*CO → *CHOHCO on CoNi-C2N, whereas at *CO+*CHO → *COCHO on CoCuN6-gra. Additionally, when the intermediates are adsorbed on the catalyst surface, the metal atom protrusion is more obvious on the CoNi-C2N catalyst than on CoCuN6-gra (Fig. S3 and S8), indicating that the latter has better stability and durability than the former. This is also consistent with the more negative formation energy of CoCuN6-gra than CoNi-C2N (−7.85 vs. −5.19 eV). Comparing Fig. 4a and Fig. 13a, the formation of *CH2CH on CoNi-C2N is energetically more favorable than the competitive *CH2CH2OH, whereas the energy difference between *CHCH2 and *CH2CH2OH is rather small on CoCuN6-gra, indicating that CoNi-C2N could exhibit enhanced selectivity for C2H4. 4 Conclusion In summary, the detailed eCO2RR process on the new CoCuN6-gra and CoNi-C2N catalysts were investigated by using DFT calculations based on both periodic and cluster models. Both of them can selectively convert CO2 to C2 products with low limiting potentials of −0.56/−0.50 V and low energy barriers of 0.56/0.62 eV. C2H4 is their main product. The key C-C coupling occurs at the *CO+*CHO → *COCHO step on CoCuN6-gra and *CHOH+*CO → *CHOHCO step on CoNi-C2N. Their good selectivity towards C2 products arises from: (1) the synergistic effect of the bimetallic active sites enables them to simultaneously adsorb two CO, as required by the C-C coupling; (2) the further hydrogenation of the co-adsorbed *CO+*CO significantly lowers the coupling energy barrier. As an obvious feature of this work, subtle wavefunction changes during the C-C coupling reactions were scrutinized by using various quantum chemistry methods. The analyses reveal that the conversion from *CO+*CO to *CO+*CHO or from *CO+*CO to *CHOH+*CO weakens the interactions between the intermediate and catalyst surface and reduces the carbon orbital contributions, shortens the C-C distance in the co-adsorbed intermediate and enhances their attractions. All these changes greatly facilitate the subsequent C-C coupling. Our work provides new insights into the important C-C coupling process on DACs. Different from usual heterogeneous catalysis studies only relying on the periodic calculations, it represents a novel research paradigm by combining both first-principles methods and powerful quantum chemistry tools, and thus can deeply disclose the reaction mechanism at the wavefunction level. The method could be further applied to understand and rationally design more catalytic materials to achieve target multicarbon products. Because electrochemical reactions usually occur under the fixed electrode potential, grand-canonical DFT calculations [70] are planned in the future to further investigate the C-C coupling mechanisms and compare with current ones based on constant charge. coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (eCO2RR) can produce fuels, valuable chemicals, and help achieve carbon neutrality. However, obtaining target C2 products (e.g., ethylene and ethanol) with high activity and selectivity is still challenging. In this work, we chose the CoCu/CoNi dual atoms incorporated N-doped graphene (CoCuN6-gra) and C2N (CoNi-C2N) as the model catalysts to study the detailed eCO2RR process by using density functional theory calculations. The results reveal that CoCuN6-gra and CoNi-C2N both exhibit good catalytic activity and selectivity for ethylene with low limiting potentials (-0.56 and -0.50 V) and energy barriers (0.56 and 0.62 eV). The C-C coupling reaction prefers to occur at the *CO+*CHO → *COCHO step on CoCuN6-gra and *CHOH+*CO → *CHOHCO step on CoNi-C2N rather than their previous *CO+*CO → *COCO. Quantum chemistry wavefunction analyses rationalize this reaction difference and further disclose that three important characteristics could help achieve the C-C coupling: (1) weakened interactions between metal site and intermediate; (2) lowered orbital components of adsorbate carbon atoms in the metal-carbon bonds; (3) reduced electrostatic repulsion between the two coupling carbon atoms after accepting electrons from the hydrogen and/or metal atoms. Our work not only demonstrates the promising eCO2RR performance of the emerging CoCuN6-gra and CoNi-C2N dual-atom catalysts, but also provides a novel and in-depth wavefunction understanding for the rational design of more electrocatalysts to obtain various multicarbon products.
